Hi <@U0331KF5TSN>
It Is really important to know how to approach clients and extract testimonials from them during the out-boarding process.

So here are some steps you could follow -

1) Highlight the benefits to the other party by letting them know you intend to distribute the case study in places that will reach their prospective customers too and it will be in social media, landing pages, newsletters and on your website.

2) Things to include in your brief for the testimonial:
-Outline your goals and objectives
- Highlight the main takeaways
- Summarize the story
- Detail the project’s nuts and bolts

3) Schedule the interview and decide on a medium of communication the client is comfortable with.

4) Keep it crisp and avoid fluff. Try to use real numbers from the project. To include infographics, headshots and data illustrations.

5) Get the data edited into an impactful video by a professional team. Get customer approval in a timely way.

6) You can offer rewards to clients in return for featuring in your testimonials. Rewards like Amazon gift cards, free or discounted service for a few months, and Amazon discount coupons are very popular.

If you are looking for a quick, done-for-you solution, I work at Content Beta, a SaaS-focused video production agency and we’ve helped ManyChat, Dynamic Yield and 60 other B2B SaaS with their video needs. Would love to chat about what you're looking for. You can check out some examples for inspiration here: <https://www.contentbeta.com/remote-video-testimonials/>

Thanks for the input <@U010JU2GTND>, I hear what you're saying about the exchange already being a win. And honestly, I was a little less inclined at first to keep chasing Canadian brands but it sounds like if you find the right personnel there could still be a good fit for both the brand and the freelancer.

And although we haven't worked together thank you for raising writer's rates from your end. I haven't struggled with this (yet) but I know from this and other communities that a lot of freelancers have a hard time charging their worth, or increasing their rates once they do become more valuable / skilled.
